C: This joseki is especially effective for White when Black [r17] has extensions around [l17] and [r10]. Black can now attack White but no longer expect much territory here (compare with what a shimari [r17]â€“[q15] would yield with  [l17]â€“[r10]). For that reason, with [l17]â€“[r10] Black may prefer to play [p18] at [r15] (see [path:qcttpittkcpdqdpeqepfqfpgqgphqhoipjmc]). [src:38bj,p. 14 Dia. 7,8]

_children.C:
Black could have tenukied, but often plays here to prevent White [r15].

Ke Jie said in 2017: In the old Joseki Black plays keima. But I don't get why the keima is needed.
Black is trying to force and make White heavy before defending.
